45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. Its racist legacy still endures todayIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

Jeneé OsterheldtBlack men dying by hanging — whether by suicide or murder — are a visceral reminder of America’s rootsAt least four Black men have died by hanging this summer, and they all have been ruled suicides. But in our society, even suicide carries the signs of racism. 9:07 a.m.

Adrian WalkerWhy is Boston standing by a racist police promotional exam?For decades, the Boston Police Department has used a standardized, multiple-choice exam to determine the sergeants who advance to a higher civil service rank. Black and Latino officers insist that the test has worked against them.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.

45 years ago, Black protesters tried to desegregate Carson Beach. The peaceful demonstration quickly turned violentIn 1975, Black Bostonians gathered for a picnic-protest on Carson Beach to assert their right to use the city’s public spaces. What started as a peaceful demonstration quickly devolved into violence between white and Black protesters, further cementing the city’s national reputation for racial rancor.
